content:
No, three does not equal one in the usual sense of mathematical equations. The doctrine of the Trinity affirms that there is one God who exists eternally and co-equally as three distinct persons - the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit - who share the same divine essence or nature.

While the Trinity may be difficult to understand fully, it does not claim that three equals one in the usual sense of mathematical equations. Instead, it affirms that the divine being is a complex unity that can be described in terms of three persons who are united in one divine essence. The concept of the Trinity seeks to reconcile the biblical affirmations of the unity and oneness of God with the biblical testimony that the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit are all God.
